dismissalText.commentary: Sean Williams c Green b Zampa 29 (45b 3x4 0x6 91m) SR: 64.44

dismissalComment.html: Thick outside edge flies to short third. Tossed up generously outside off, it was the wrong one. Williams looks to go drive it over the off side but gets the outside edge. Green runs to his right and pouches that with a dive. Zimbabwe's major hope falls.

dismissalText.commentary: Sikandar Raza c Stoinis b Hazlewood 17 (37b 1x4 1x6 40m) SR: 45.94

dismissalComment.html: taken at deep square leg, and Raza's brief party ends already! Gets another short ball, but this is on off, and rising on to the batter. He has to leap in the crease to get on top of the bounce - unlike the one off which he hit four, this was straighter - and ends up getting a top edge. He hit ten off the over already, but never looked in control of this shot. Zimbabwe lose another in a hurry

image.caption: Innocent Kaia, player portrait 2022
image.longCaption: Innocent Kaia, player portrait 2022

headshotImage.caption: Innocent Kaia, player page headshot cutout 2022
headshotImage.longCaption: Innocent Kaia, player page headshot cutout 2022

dismissalComment.html: The perfect yorker from Starc! The late inswing does Kaia in and Australia are truly underway in Townsville. Spears it very full just outside off, getting to swing it back in ever so late. Kaia looks to jam it out but is beaten by the inward movement. Beaten for pace and the ball kisses the off stump. No real footwork from the Zimbabwe opener there. A wicket-maiden for Starc.

image.caption: Wessley Madhevere, player portrait
image.longCaption: Wessley Madhevere, player portrait

headshotImage.caption: Wessley Madhevere player page headshot cutout 2021
headshotImage.longCaption: Wessley Madhevere player page headshot cutout 2021

dismissalComment.html: Huge appeal and given! Starc is on a roll. Madhevere seems to be trapped in front and he talks with his partner about a review but has been dissuaded by Marumani. Full and swinging in on middle and leg, he misses the flick and is struck on the pad. Umpire's call on impact, shows the Hawk-Eye. Zimbabwe rocked early today and the hero with the bat in the first game is gone.

image.caption: Tadiwanashe Marumani, player portrait 2022
image.longCaption: Tadiwanashe Marumani, player portrait 2022

headshotImage.caption: Tadiwanashe Marumani, player page headshot cutout 2022
headshotImage.longCaption: Tadiwanashe Marumani, player page headshot cutout 2022

dismissalComment.html: Third wicket for Starc and he is one away from 200! Catching practice for substitute Labuschagne at forward square leg. Angles it full on middle and leg, Marumani absolutely middles the flick but straight to the fielder. This is getting bad to worse for Zimbabwe.

image.longCaption: Luke Jongwe, player portrait 2022

headshotImage.caption: Luke Jongwe, player page headshot cutout 2022
headshotImage.longCaption: Luke Jongwe, player page headshot cutout 2022

dismissalComment.html: Bowled him off the back pad! Quicker one on a length, it is the flipper. It bounces more, beats Jongwe's attempted punch off the back foot, goes off the top of the back pad to hit the leg stump.

image.caption: Brad Evans, player portrait 2022
image.longCaption: Brad Evans, player portrait 2022

headshotImage.caption: Brad Evans, player page headshot cutout 2022
headshotImage.longCaption: Brad Evans, player page headshot cutout 2022

dismissalComment.html: Trapped in front! Zampa finishes with three to skittle out ZImbabwe for 96. Evans takes the customary review, unless he has inside-edged that. Tossed up wrong one on middle and off, Evans goes for the slog across the line but is hit on the back leg that is adjacent. He actually signaled for the review almost immediately. Did he inside edge it or did the bat hit the ground? Yep, bat hitting the ground, no contact with the bat. The Snicko perhaps fails to load but the TV umpire looks at the Hotspot to rule out the edge. Umpire's call on hitting as it just clips the stumps.

dismissalText.commentary: Regis Chakabva c Starc b Agar 10 (14b 2x4 0x6 12m) SR: 71.42

dismissalComment.html: another wicket given away in pursuit of attack! This ball looks to be a bit fuller than the one he hit a four off two balls earlier, but he opened the bat face to slice this above the in field. Didn't time it at all, and found mid-off, where Starc had to move a few steps to his left to catch it after the ball was ballooned

commentTextItems.html: he decides to be a left-hander or so, and spotting that, Williams fires it full and flat outside leg. Smith misses his attempted reverse swing, and the ball races away for byes

commentPostTextItems.html: 1:15pm Well then. Zimbabwe will have to have a hard look at their batting once again as the final game beckons on Saturday. Will they put up a better show then? As for Australia, Finch's returns with the bat could be a concern for them. Will they look to bat first in the final ODI? Do join us on Saturday to find out. That's all we have for you today. I, Sudarshanan, sign off on behalf of Vairavan and Himanshu. Adios!

Aaron Finch, Australia captain: "I thought [bowling] was clinical. The tone set by Starc and Hazlewood was terrific. Couldn't have gone more to plan there. [Carey at No. 4] I think we have to be flexible and understand where you play. Over the next little while, we have to keep experimenting with the different ways to play one day cricket. I have chatted to the boys about flexibility in selection. You just want to keep playing good cricket regardless of the result."

Regis Chakabva, Zimbabwe captain: "I thought Oz bowled really well at us. They used the wicket well and we did not get the guys going and it is unfortunate. It is huge. [On touring Australia] We always want to play against the best. When we came here we knew it was going to be a test for us. I thought the first game went well but today, a lot's to take back. Even though we had a very low total, the bowlers came fighting hard."

Mitchell Starc, player of the match for his three-for: "Few conversations on the golf course. The wicket had a good covering of the grass and was a bit poppy and tennis-ball like ball. Josh and I had to be a bit fuller and attack the stumps more. Our powerplay was good today and the bowling was a big tick today. [Smith] He looked to take the game on and that's the Steve we have seen ten-plus years. He is striking the ball nicely."
Hang around for the presentation, which Suds will bring to you.

Sarthak: "Pretty hard to look beyond Maxi for captainship for LOIs I think. Marsh might be the next best if he wasn't on a hospital bed every month. None of the other guys are regulars in both ODIs and T20Is."
John: "I personally think you can carry a specialist captain in t20 cricket, as bowling/fielding tactics are so important in such a short game. Just my view anyway"

1.32pm Barely a contest, although the entertainment with those two early Australian wickets looked good while it lasted. No trouble after that, as Smith batted like Warner would have loved to - and Finch would have at least hoped to - and carried his side home. Starc set it up early with the ball, and Zimbabwe never recovered after those three early blows. In the end, Australia win with more than 35 overs left.

commentTextItems.html: reverse swept over point! Rolls his wrists to this full ball outside off, and gets into position early to send that aerially. And it is a no-ball
good length ball going on with the angle, and clipped to fine leg
short again, and again turning down leg. He shoulders arms, and they steal a run off a wide
short and slow on off. Punched to long-on

commentPostTextItems.html: Gareth: "I have no idea why Maxi gets overlooked for the national captaincy in the shorter forms. He's a shrewd operator and shows in his batting, bowling and fielding, and is already one of the first consulted when it comes to tactics and field placings. Give the Big Show the Big Job."

dismissalText.commentary: Innocent Kaia b Starc 2 (8b 0x4 0x6 16m) SR: 25

dismissalComment.html: The perfect yorker from Starc! The late inswing does Kaia in and Australia are truly underway in Townsville. Spears it very full just outside off, getting to swing it back in ever so late. Kaia looks to jam it out but is beaten by the inward movement. Beaten for pace and the ball kisses the off stump. No real footwork from the Zimbabwe opener there. A wicket-maiden for Starc.

Zimbabwe rocked early today and the hero with the bat in the first game is gone.

dismissalText.commentary: Brad Evans lbw b Zampa 2 (6b 0x4 0x6 10m) SR: 33.33

dismissalComment.html: Trapped in front! Zampa finishes with three to skittle out ZImbabwe for 96. Evans takes the customary review, unless he has inside-edged that. Tossed up wrong one on middle and off, Evans goes for the slog across the line but is hit on the back leg that is adjacent. He actually signaled for the review almost immediately. Did he inside edge it or did the bat hit the ground? Yep, bat hitting the ground, no contact with the bat. The Snicko perhaps fails to load but the TV umpire looks at the Hotspot to rule out the edge. Umpire's call on hitting as it just clips the stumps.

dismissalText.commentary: Innocent Kaia b Starc 2 (8b 0x4 0x6 16m) SR: 25

dismissalComment.html: The perfect yorker from Starc! The late inswing does Kaia in and Australia are truly underway in Townsville. Spears it very full just outside off, getting to swing it back in ever so late. Kaia looks to jam it out but is beaten by the inward movement. Beaten for pace and the ball kisses the off stump. No real footwork from the Zimbabwe opener there. A wicket-maiden for Starc.

Full and swinging in on middle and leg, he misses the flick and is struck on the pad. Umpire's call on impact, shows the Hawk-Eye. Zimbabwe rocked early today and the hero with the bat in the first game is gone.

dismissalComment.html: nabbed by Raza in a double attempt at first slip! Ngarava in no mood to give up despite only 97 to defend. Finch jabs at that unconvincingly - he was neither forward to that back of a length ball angling across off, nor back. In the end, it was a half-poke with a little jump in the crease while even giving the impression that he was convinced he could leave it, but the ball took the outside edge

headshotImage.longCaption: DA Warner headshot

dismissalComment.html: very good catch by deep third! Evans in the deep went forward and low to grab that just above the ground. Warner continues to be funky, but this time falls. He made room, and took a few steps down the pitch to try and hack that good length ball outside off. It was a wild swat in the end, as the ball took off from the top edge

dismissalComment.html: nabbed by Raza in a double attempt at first slip! Ngarava in no mood to give up despite only 97 to defend. Finch jabs at that unconvincingly - he was neither forward to that back of a length ball angling across off, nor back. In the end, it was a half-poke with a little jump in the crease while even giving the impression that he was convinced he could leave it, but the ball took the outside edge
